But when I first listened to \\"Binaural\\", I have to admit that I was not crazy about it. Perhaps it's because I was going through a real depressing and lame time of my life at the time- I don't know. The songs just seemed to totally match the way I felt at the time, which wasn't all that good. But being a COMPLETE Pearl Jam fanatic, I was faithful and gave this album several listens. But I was still not getting it due to the rut I was in. A year later, I moved to a different state and started driving truck again and my life really cheered up. It was then that I gave this album another chance. Gradually I began getting it- it began growing on me more and more with every listen and I all of a sudden fell in love with it. Able to not associate it with a dreary chapter in my life, for once I was actually able to see the true beauty of \\"Binaural\\". That compounded with seeing many of the tracks LIVE on the DVD \\"Pearl Jam: Touring Band 2000\\" really sold me to this incredible album. For the life of me I couldn't understand what I didn't like about it at first. Sure, it's different from \\"Yield\\", but it's SUPPOSED TO BE! That's what Pearl Jam is all about, and it's different in a VERY GOOD way. It's very dark and moody for a Pearl Jam album, but it works very well at the same time. It's got a really \\"atmospheric\\" sound and feel to it which I have grown to love. It's almost like the kind of music you'd expect to hear while hanging out in outer-space looking out at the Hourglass Nebula encircling a dying star, the exact image of the incredible album cover! But don't get me wrong- there are plenty of hard rockers on the album as well that seem to fit in PERFECTLY with the rest of the batch. The only filler on the ENTIRE album is \\"Soon Forget\\", and it's actually not that bad for filler. \\"Evacuation\\" takes quite a while to get into, it was the last song that finally started to grow on me. But once you get it, you get it. The album's hard rockers are \\"Breakerfall\\", \\"God's Dice\\" (What a name!), \\"Evacuation\\", \\"Grievance\\" (Another one that takes a few listens to appreciate, but once you do, you love it), and \\"Rival\\" (kind of reminded me of \\"No Way\\" off \\"Yield\\", same over-all raw vibe and good sound). All the rest of the tracks are EXCEPTIONAL slower tracks that are VERY deep and entrancing, as well as VERY beautiful. Stand-outs are the unbelievable radio hit, \\"Nothing As It Seems\\", \\"Of The Girl\\", \\"Sleight Of Hand\\" (one of my favorites off the album- sounds really atmospheric) and the ultimate album closer, \\"Parting Ways\\" (in which Eddie ends the album by singing, \\"drifting away...drifting away...\\" over and over). This has got to be my third most favorite Pearl Jam album of all time. Very good stuff from beginning to end- it's a real journey once you realize it's beauty and quality. But be prepared- it IS a darker sounding album, and because of that you might not like it at first. But trust me- give it a few listens and your jaw will soon drop in appreciation for a truly powerful album. Don't be like me and expect another \\"Yield\\" or any other album you may have liked- this one's different. But that's what makes it so entrancingly fantastic- it's very unique. Buy \\"Binaural\\" and give it a chance- you'll be happy you did.

While some were not knowing what to think of \\"Vitalogy\\" and \\"No Code\\", they were pleasantly surprised with \\"Yield\\". Give it a try- you won't regret it.

B000002BFZ|4.0|After a somewhat disappointing \\"Vitalogy\\", Pearl Jam comes back with a powerful album entitled \\"No Code\\". If you were over all not pleased with \\"Vitalogy\\", you should give this album a try. It is probably one of their most experimental album to date, which seems to turn some people off. But in my opinion, this album is very solid and a pleasure to listen to. It was a time when Pearl Jam entered a new chapter in their career, and they seemed to step out of the dark closet that they were so buried in when they recorded \\"Vitalogy\\". It's been a couple years since Kurt Cobain's tragic suicide and a time when Pearl Jam were considering to quit the business all together. But they pulled through this tough time and put out a much better and focused album than \\"Vitalogy\\" could ever dream of being. \\"No Code\\" starts off with a very mellow but good track, \\"Sometimes\\", and then explodes with a hard \\"Hail, Hail\\" that is right up there with \\"Animal\\" and \\"Whipping\\" to name a couple. Then comes a little experimentation with \\"Who You Are\\" that really catches on after a few listens. So after the first three tracks alone, you know you are in for an interesting album. Through out \\"No Code\\", you hear a very raw but heavy sound, which after a couple listens really sounds great. You also hear dashes of Neil Young's influence every once in a while(Pearl Jam had done some work with him from time to time like \\"Mirror Ball\\"). With \\"No Code\\" it seems like the mellow tracks are mixed in just great with the harder tracks, and it sounds fairly consistent. And unlike \\"Vitalogy\\", this album only has ONE filler track, \\"Lukin\\", which isn't even that bad comparitively speaking. It's just super fast, hard, and short. The album's only weaker track is \\"Mankind\\", which follows a very good and impressive \\"Present Tense\\". Guitarist Stone Gossard (who, with Bassist Jeff Ament, started the group back in '91) sings for \\"Mankind\\" and it just doesn't sound that good. It seems kind of out of place on such a good album. But  after the rest of the album being so good, you can easily forgive and forget \\"Mankind\\". But who knows- you might like it anyway; I know a few people who do. So over all, \\"No Code\\" is a very good album and after \\"Vitalogy\\", it's like a breath of fresh air. Even the experimentation really grows on you after a while, and you get the feeling that the band was really trying to reinvent themselves here, and they did a real good job at that. It's a safe bet with \\"No Code\\". You should get it for \\"In My Tree\\" alone- that's perhaps the album's best and considered by many fans to be a Pearl Jam classic.

B0006SSOHC|5.0|Thrillers have gone and gone over the years without much notice.  For every great film, there were a dozen or more lackluster films thrown into the realm for no apparent purpose.  Saw follows the trend, but there are more than a few reasons that this film breathes new life into a rapidly dying genre. <br /> <br />This film places Adam and Lawrence in a single room.  Their objectives:  for one of them, it is to escape the room; for the other, it is to kill his fellow prisoner (otherwise, his family dies).  Following in the wake of Seven, this movie centers around the Jigsaw Killer (renowned for allowing his victims to find ways to kill themselves) and the puzzle that he presents the unlucky prisoners.  From start to finish, the movie unravels bit by bit, slowly revealing critical details of the plot surrounding the main characters, the killer, and several of the side characters as well.  Along the way, there are some truly memorable scenes (Adam's hunt for the murderer in the dark using his camera's flash) and more than one or two haunting images (a young woman who rips through a man's stomach to find the key needed to save her). <br /> <br />Two constant themes with most films of this type are the intelligence of the villain and evil often being able to outwit good.  Both properties are well emphasized here.  I won't spoil anything, but I can also say with confidence that the ending is not happy, and it's definitely not what you'll be expecting. <br /> <br />Though the acting is nothing spectacular and the movie was significantly underfunded, Saw entrances the viewer with a sweet, manaical storyline, an intricate cast of characters, and plot twist after unforgettable plot twist.  All in all, it ranks as one of the best films 2004 had to offer, resulting as a sinister combination of Seven and Identity.  It would be a true sin for any fan of psychological thrillers not to own this movie.

This film garnered mixed reviews throughout 2004, but after seeing it, I have no idea why.  From start to finish, Depp's performance intrigues, from the ridiculous attire he wears at home to the cynical comments he makes to others.  The plot, as would be expected from a Stephen King story, is well crafted, and it builds progressively from start to finish.  In the end, the viewer is satisfied by a sweet, dark ending that Stephen King is so renowned for creating.  Secret Window was probably the most overlooked great film that 2004 had to offer.

B0000524CY|5.0|In retrospect, this has to be considered one of the top 25 American films of the second half of the 20th century.  The reason I am citing here in particular is the overt and powerful emphasis on the external.  Let's see what that means.<br /><br />American culture has always had a practical, \\"can do\\" orientation--a perspective that has consistently (at least since the advent of the Industrial Revolution, if not before) emphasized the accomplishment of goals through work.  That is, there's been a sledgehammer-like insistence, decade after decade, on the Protestant work ethic (also called Judeo-Christian work ethic).  The corollary of this emphasis is that any problems that arise do so based on external circumstances.  While there have been great American works of art pointing in the opposite direction (Miller's Death of a Salesman is a terrific example), these have not detracted from the still present today work ethic that informs how we live, work, and relate to each other.<br /><br />The Exorcist is much more than a horror film.  It's a potent drama that slams the viewer in the face with just how embedded we are in this Protestant/Judeo-Christian ethic by positing one of the worst problems ever (loss of control over one's actions) solely on the basis of an external influence--i.e., demonic possession.<br /><br />The reason this film works so incredibly well is that the writer, William Peter Blatty, and the director, William Friedkin, were both smart enough to know that shock for shock's sake and all the grotesque tricks that little Regan pulls as a demon (the spider walk, the 360 degree head turn, etc.) don't add up to a hill of beans unless the demonically possessed little girl is contrasted with her opponents who are themselves riddled with problems.  Thus, the source of the extreme problem--a blatantly external influence (demon)--meets other external influences (this time on the side of good) whose own internal lives are in chaos.<br /><br />What this does, interestingly enough, is to emphasize even more how obvious the American perspective on the external really is. Why?  Because in spite of their doubts and fears, these two priests are committed to fighting this external influence, this demon, until, come Hell or high water, they win.  And in this film, yes, Hell does come.  It's really pretty amazing how strong a drama this is, after more than 30 years, and how weak and pathetic many other copycat films are in comparison.<br /><br />The Exorcist succeeds both in scaring us because of its relentless insistence on the external vs. the internal, and in providing a cinematic work that does not rely primarily on jolts (though it certainly does have its share of those), but on the emotional depths to which those affected by this extreme of external influence can sink. Regan's mother, played by Ellen Burstyn--who gives a powerhouse performance--is, in fact, the real star of the show, running the gamut of eomtions from exuberance to complete despair.<br /><br />Max von Sydow and Jason Miller as the priests are also great, and in an uncharacteristic role--i.e., not as a heavy--Lee J. Cobb comes off well, though he doesn't have much to do, as a detective who's baffled by the goings on.<br /><br />A remarkable piece of work that is still fresh in 2005, The Exorcist is a film to add to any collection of best American cinema in the last 50 years.does, interestingly enough, is to emphasize even more how obvious the American perspective on the external really is. Why?  Because in spite of their doubts and fears, these two priests are committed to fighting this external influence, this demon, until, come Hell or high water, they win.  And in this film, yes, Hell does come.  It's really pretty amazing how strong a drama this is, after more than 30 years, and how weak and pathetic many other copycat films are in comparison.   <br /> <br />The Exorcist succeeds both in scaring us because of its relentless insistence on the external vs. the internal, and in providing a cinematic work that does not rely primarily on jolts (though it certainly does have its share of those), but on the emotional depths to which those affected by this extreme of external influence can sink. Regan's mother, played by Ellen Burstyn--who gives a powerhouse performance--is, in fact, the real star of the show, running the gamut of eomtions from exuberance to complete despair. <br /> <br />Max von Sydow and Jason Miller as the priests are also great, and in an uncharacteristic role--i.e., not as a heavy--Lee J. Cobb comes off well, though he doesn't have much to do, as a detective who's baffled by the goings on.   <br /> <br />A remarkable piece of work that is still fresh in 2005, The Exorcist is a film to add to any collection of best American cinema in the last 50 years.
B00067ZONA|4.0|From what I had read on the Genesis website I was anticpating that this mix would have far less redundency with TURN IT ON AGAIN -THE HITS (1999) than it does.  The content runs in reverse chronological order, in terms of the featured albums (Calling all Stations notwithstanding).  Do they think listeners would be turn off if they started at the beginning?<br />Disc 3 features selections from the Gabriel years.  The only major omissions that stick out here are Watchers of the Sky and perhaps Sour Turns to Sweet (if for no other reason than having a token track from the first album). They should have put In The Cage instead of Carpet (the 99 version is far better anyway) or Counting. Kudos for including the some prog classics: Knife, Supper, Fifth.<br />Disc 2 features the pre-superstardom Collins years 76-81.  There are many alternative tracks that could have gone on here.<br />Disc 1 features the superstardom years 84-97.  Most of this was already on TURN IT ON AGAIN.  Too bad they have the edit version of Tonight, the album version is best track of the Collins era.<br />Rather than featuring the same stuff that was already on TURN IT AGAIN, this collection would have been better off featuring more of the overlooked material.  That said, 3CDs does provide space for many fan-favourite album tracks.<br />At any rate this collections does give you the (more of less) best of both worlds - and hopefully it will introduce many listeners to the band's excellent 70s material.<br />The catch is that real fans would already have all their albums, while many casual fans who are only familiar with the hits would find TURN IT ON AGAIN a more economical selection.

B00006879E|5.0|I'm a sucker for good vocals. As such, I hope you can understand why I hate a lot of what's on the radio these days. <br /> <br />Thankfully, Maroon 5 has become a saving grace. I'm pleased to find a band and a disc that crosses boundaries and remains fresh and creative. <br /> <br />Songs About Jane is primarily a showcase for the amazing talents of frontman Adam Levine. Vocally, Adam draws from Steve Wonder, George Michael and Sting; lyrically, the imagery is equal parts Bernie Taupin and Joni Mitchell. The result is simply stunning. <br /> <br />Tracks such as \\"Sunday Morning\\" provide astoundingly deep but approachable lyrics; phrases like \\"Sunday morning, rain is falling / Steal some covers, share some skin / Clouds are shrouding us in moments unforgettable / You twist to fit the mold that I am in\\" are absolute poetry that any songwriter would envy. <br />Add in some double-entendres that would make George or Prince smile (\\"I tried my best to feed her appetite / Keep her coming every night / So hard to keep her satisfied\\"), and you've got a  fun edge that keeps the disc youthful and energetic. <br /> <br />Coupled with Levine's delicate but powerful vocals, the songs take on a life; these are tracks you can FEEL. Helping them along is a tight band that combines the best of R&B grooves with modern rock. The sound is the best of different worlds coming together. <br /> <br />This isn't another \\"number band\\" that aspires to be punk or \\"alternative\\"; nor is it a disc that tries to be \\"hip\\" and \\"funky.\\" What it is is an honest appreciation of music and a clever sense of creativity. <br /> <br />I hate to be so esoteric, but Songs About Jane is just that deep. I can't do one of those \\"Track #5 rocks! WHOOO!\\" reviews because there is simply too much to discuss here. Bottom line: Think Stevie Wonder, Sting, Matchbox 20. <br /> <br />I think you'll agree: Maroon 5 will be loved.

Kiddies, just because a critic in Rolling Stone or whatever thought he heard some JD influence in this doesn't mean you all have to be \\"hip\\" and start saying the same thing. Just so you know...the band don't even listen to Joy Division (except for Carlos D but I doubt he's responsible for their ultimate sound). Why don't you be creative and compare them to another band? Everyone is sick and tired of hearing you little hipsters drone on about how they ripped off Joy Division...it's not new, and it's not clever. I've heard enough JD to recognize some similarities, but I'm not dumb enough to go off and say Interpol are ripping them off. Yeah, so Paul's vocals do sound something like Ian Curtis' but who can blame the vocal chords??? Then again...why not compare Paul to Jim Morrison? Or even Neil Young? They sound kinds of alike....why fixate on Curtis? I personally love the way Paul sounds. No, it's not some sort of BEAUTIFUL, talented singing, but it sounds perfect with the music. Imagine if Paul's voice sounded like Lou Reed's.... it would take away the charm from the music. <br /> <br />Anyways, onto the actual album.... <br />All the songs seem to have sort of a 'dark' element to them without sounding too depressing or angry. The first track is mainly an instrumental one, without many vocals. This is one of my least favorite tracks as I find it repetitive and even kind of boring at times. \\"Obstacle 1\\", however, is one of the best songs on the album. The guitar chords are so simple and don't require much technique but with Paul's vocals howling over the guitar, it sounds incredible. People often say Paul sings in monotone and that they don't feel any emotion in his voice. If you are one of those people, listen to this song and you will be proven wrong. If you listen to the song as a whole, you might not have much reaction to it, but if you listen to every single element of the song (the drums, the guitar, the bass, and especially the vocals) separately you start to feel it. The same emotion can be felt in \\"The New\\". I can see how in this song he does mostly sing in a monotone fashion, yet I still feel the emotion in his lyrics. The song is pretty dynamic too, changing from a mellow beginning to a more emotional 'chorus' with Paul crying out his lyrics, and then finally changing to an almost fully instrumental ending of the next 4 minutes or so. Once again, this instrumental is ridiculously simple, with the guitar chords hardly changing but it doesn't require any impressive skills to make it sound mesmerizing. <br /> <br />Now I have to mention \\"Stella Was a Diver and She Was Always Down\\". This is SUCH a great song. It's somewhat mellow, dynamic, and the drums and bass work incredibly well together. Here I do agree that there's not too much emotion in his voice except when he sings \\"she broke away, broke away\\". It's like I hear him WANTING to belt those lyrics out even louder. When he sings \\"Stella...Stella....Oh Stella....Stella I love you, Stella I love you, Stella I love you\\" I have to close my eyes and concentrate those tiny, almost inaudible vocal changes. When you concentrate that hard, you feel the emotion practically exploding within the song. <br />Now....Leif Erikson....when I first listened to the album in its entirety, I thought the song was boring and I skipped over it every time. I didn't start to like it until a month or more after listening to the album. It's a beautiful closer with strange lyrics, but somehow they compel me. <br /> <br />Excellent debut; I don't know how they could've made it any better than it is.
B0006399FS|2.0|I simply couldn't bring myself to accept this music. Last night I decided to give it another shot, start to finish. This experience only confirmed one thing: this is their very worst album. Bono and The Edge are really sub-par lyricists, and the lyrics are obviously meant to ape the themes found in Joshua Tree era recordings. Do you think Bono was really all that concerned about talking and intimacy, or he and the men needed an excuse to tour and make bajillions of dollars again? The very lowest point is the horrible, horrible, HORRIBLE pieces \\"A Man And A Woman\\" and \\"Sometimes You Can't...\\".  <br /> <br />Bono is now among the most low quality rough struggle singers I've ever heard, and I haven't heard lyrics that awful and trite since the last time I heard Lenny Kravitz's \\"Dragonfly\\" which thankfully has not been for a long time. There are some nice moments (and I do mean moments, like two- or three-second snippets) here and there, but all in all, U2's playing is nowhere near as ferocious as it was on War, Pop or even Rattle & Hum stand-out tracks like \\"Desire\\" or \\"God Part 2\\" (one Bono's best moments), and his voice isn't as strong and pure as it used to be.  <br /> <br />Then there are all the obligatory U2isms: Edge's trademark guitars, keyboards, \\"epic\\" sound and \\"Joshua Tree\\" production, mid tempo songs, Bono's rough \\"emotional\\" voice, a slower B-side, distant and the like. I've read that upon hearing ATYLCB, as Roger Waters called \\"Pink Floyd\\" A Momentary Lapse Of Reason something like \\"a clever, quite facile forgery,\\" and I agree. ATYCLB used some U2 cliches just to maintain an \\"authentic\\" atmosphere, but that album was just as awful and cheap through and through as this one. HTDAAB like \\"Star Wars, Episode One,\\" is a disappointing, worthless example of totally formulaic drivel. If you're still a U2 fan and this CD gives you some sort of satisfaction, then you must be a total lunkhead, because in even the most objective sense this album absolutely reeks. <br /> <br />It seems likely that this `band' is now doing studio albums merely as an excuse to tour, under the pretense that they aren't a has been nostalgia act, and perhaps because there's is more morning in a tour, than doing a good studio album. B0006399FS|4.0|Get over it, guys. Get a life. And while you're at it, get a little perspective. U2 hasn't made a great album since 1991, so why is everyone so surprised this isn't an instant classic? For the love of Christ, what's with all the hateful reviews here? If you're annoyed with the iPod commercial, don't buy one. If you're furious over ticket sale screw-ups, go sue. But don't relieve your frustration by pouring scorn on this album which, like the last, is no major breakthrough but otherwise just fine. Apart from the slight misstep that was \\"Pop\\", for twenty-five years U2 has been the world's most consistently excellent rock act. Full credit to Daniel Lanois for inventing their classic sound, but kudos to the boys for pushing it through every reinvention imaginable while only occasionally losing sight of the things that make it great. \\"How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb\\" gives it a twist, one more lyrically and musically adventurous than 2000's \\"All That You Can't Leave Behind\\" which was a necessarily conservative return to form. Tracks like 'Miracle Drug', 'Sometimes You Can't Make It On Your Own' and 'City of Blinding Lights' take the anthem-ballads U2 are best at and trick them out with both sonic experimentation (especially in the rhythm section) and renewed sensitivity, while the opener, 'Vertigo', shows what four master craftsmen and a good producer can still do with a solid rock hook and no shame. 'One Step Closer' is as delicate and beautiful as anything they've done , 'Yahweh' is a masterclass in subtle engineering and arrangement, and 'Crumbs From Your Table' is possibly the pick of the album. This is confident, forthright, interesting music from a band who knows who they are. It also proves that when they stray too far from the Lanois/Eno template, it doesn't always work. But so what? What's wrong with a little variety now and then? It's obviously nowhere near the level of their masterworks - \\"War\\", \\"The Joshua Tree\\" and the peerless \\"Achtung Baby\\" - but it does deliver a few of those magical U2 moments where Bono's lyrics and the Edge's guitars conspire to have your spine tingling and your heart blown open at precisely the same moment.eliver a few of those magical U2 moments where Bono's lyrics and the Edge's guitars conspire to have your spine tingling and your heart blown open at precisely the same moment. <br />
B00005JN2Z|5.0|Both Jamie Foxx and Tom Cruise deserved Best Actor nominations for this movie, Michael Mann deserved Best Director, and this should have been nominated for Best Cinematography and Best Film. Jamie Foxx is a lead in this movie and was actually nominated for Best Supporting Actor, not sure what is with that-is an actor not allowed to have two Best Actor nominations? Tom Cruise plays the best professional killer since the original Terminator, and there is even a homage to that movie in the club shoot-out. But Tom plays a human, not a machine, and truly deserves Best Actor for his performance. Allegedly Tom Cruise had never fired a real gun before training for this movie, and his pure-speed athleticism shows off with the two street thugs and the takedown in the club, where Cruise is so fast you can only fully understand the action when watching it in slow motion. In the Director's commentary, Michael Mann waxes eloquently on the digital camera photography and the artsy visual poetry is in the beautiful night scenes of Los Angeles. The cinematography is so beautiful that it can almost be enjoyed by itself with the sound off-- like the scene where the taxi stops while two coyotes cross the street. There's clever camera work like the \\"falling camera\\" shown just before the body hits the top of the taxi. But by turning off the sound you'd miss the clever dialog and soundtrack. The comeback to the accusatory \\"You killed him!\\" is one of the best movie lines of all time: \\"No, I shot him. Bullets and the fall killed him.\\" The AudioSlave scoring from the coyote scene to the club shootout is in itself worth buying the CD, which also includes the Miles Davis jazz scene. But like an iceberg, this movie is really about what is going on underneath the psyche of the two men: the sociopath's cold heart is slowly being pierced while the procrastinator is finally forced to face his complete lack of leadership and initiative for action. Quite simply, this is not only the best movie of 2004but one of the best movies of all time. Watch it once \\"as is\\", then watch it again to slo-mo Tom Cruise's action secenes, then watch it again with Michael Mann's commentary. Fantastic!

B0002S94OS|4.0|Sometimes a major record label's big production job can be a good thing. The production on \\"Ashes of the Wake\\" is better than that of \\"As the Palaces Burn\\", and the end result is good.  <br /> <br />The full-on metal/thrash attack is still in tact (Lamb of God did not add any melody to this album), but Randy Blythe's vocals are more interesting (and they're done in a way that the listener can discern what he's saying--most of the time.) Blythe belts out a Cookie Monster yell/growl about 90% of the time, but he also shrieks and says the occasional spoken word. But the biggest change here is that his voice's pitch is more diverse than on the last album. This also adds some needed texture to Lamb's music. <br /> <br />Drummer Chris Adler can go from a wild, machine gun attack and death metal blasts to a slow chug (\\"Break You\\" is a good example this.) The blowtorch guitar riffs are pretty insane too; they're thrashy, crunchy and fast. All the while, Blythe is bashing war, President Bush, and pretty much all forms of authority.  <br /> <br />\\"Laid to Rest\\" opens with a pouding beat and a shriek. It then turns to a grinding lurch which gains speed off of itself, and around the two and half minute mark, the riffs and drums turn to a bobbing beat. <br />\\"Now You've Got Something to Die For\\" opens with another shriek, which is still ringing in my ears. The beat begins by grooving, while the drums are pummeling and the song eventually turns to a thunderous, \\"boom-boom\\".  <br />\\"Blood of the Scribe\\" begins as a very speedy song, but then a beat/speed change kick in and slows things down. The guitars churn out fast chug-chug riffs, but then change and make almost a beeping noise. <br />\\"Ashes of the Wake\\" is a personal favorite. A recorded voice (from what sounds like a CNN report) begins the track, but for the most part this song is a six-minute long instrumental track featuring five (albeit short) guitar solos from Megadeth's Chris Poland and Testament's Alex Skolnick (I'd say the third, winding guitar solo is my favorite.)  <br />\\"Remorse is For the Dead\\" begins with slow, dwindling soft guitar chords, which eventually stop and things kick into first gear for the typical Lamb of God assault. <br /> <br />So, this album is the band's best work to date. Some say they are the modern day equivalent of Slayer or Pantera, and while I don't think they're that good, I think they definitely have the potential and talent to be.  <br /> <br />Even though they are different than other New Wave of American Heavy Metal band's (due to the almost constant double bass drumming and death metal growl), it's essential for fans of The New Wave. I also recommend it if you're new to The New Wave, or if you're a metal/thrash fan.

B0000AOV85|5.0|We are all fans of DSOTM, you know.   <br /> <br />This symphonic rock concept album changed expectations of rock music forever.  Roger Waters and the Floyd developed their theme in this album the way a great symphonist from the 18th Century develops one.   <br /> <br />DSOTM transcends all other concept albums in this development.  It is unique in Rock history.  <br /> <br />This DVD, on of the Classic Album Series, is the story of this development.  It is, by the way, the best of all the \\"Classic Albums\\" DVD's in my opinion.   <br /> <br />Of course, the technical aspects are covered in detail (\\"just how did they synch all those clocks?\\") and looking over the mixing board and listening in on the original tapes is really fun.  <br /> <br />Even better is how the artists each reproduce performances which are then synched with the album.  Every time this happens, it's magical to watch.   <br /> <br />But the best part of this DVD is how each artist in turn lays down his rancor and tells the story of how this magical album comes together.  In the end, they are simple and honest, each realizing that the other contributed some part of this thing that became much greater than the whole.  <br /> <br />Pink Floyd will likely never collaborate again;  maybe they've said what they had to say.  For sure,  all the anger that flowed between them would be a giant ogre sitting on their shoulders.  So it's really nice to see this DVD, where they pay homage to each other, and to the incredible thing they made decades ago.

B00009V7T2|5.0|Even though I was a fan of At the Drive-In, I wasn't all that excited about The Mars Volta, cause everything I read about them talked as it they were gonna be a avant-garde psychedelic latin space jazz band or some such thing.  Something like that *could* be good, but that sounded like it was so far from what ATDI was that who the hell could tell.  It didn't even sound like they were gonna be a rock band. So I wasn't too interested.  Shortly after it 'De-Loused in the Comatorium' was released one of my friends got it, and I listened to it and was stunned by how rockin and excellent it was.  Yeah it's got jazz and psychedelic and latin flavoring, but it's all filtered through the basic ATDI post-hardcore style, making this a bizarre, prog-post-hardcore album, and still essentially an extension of ATDI style and ethic.  It a rather sever extension, admittedly, but the connection is eminently obvious.  Anyway, this is a fantastic, flawless album which is also my favorite album from 2003.<br /><br />Even though this is essentially a modern prog-rock album, it has all the energy and intensity you'd here on an ATDI album.  Many people out there seem to hate Cedric's shrieky, high-pitched vocals, but I think he's fantastic, and one of the most emotionally powerful vocalists around.  I can understand why some people hate him, as I hated him when I first heard ATDI, but most these people just need to lighten up and try to get into it.  The new rhythm work is fantastic, with  memorable, pulsing basslines, lots of frenetic, jazz-inflected drumwork and quite a bit of additional percussion.  There is a fair bit of leadwork on this album, though most of is not your typical guitar-heroic stuff, and the rhythm work is still largely jagged post-hardcore type stuff.  There's lots of electronics and keyboard stuff, and it generally works quite well and fleshes out the overall sound.  The organ is particularly nice.<br /><br />There are 8 full-length tracks on here, and they're all very good to excellent.  'Inertiac ESP' is one of the more straight forward tracks, nice and energetic and catchy.  'Roulette Dares' ups the experimentation with some low-key jazz interludes, and a blistering, memorable riff under the chorus, and excellent vocal work all around.  'Drunkship of Lanterns' is one of the more unique pieces, a more atmospheric song with an unrelenting, nervy rhythm section and amelodic, snapping guitar lines.  Arguably the weakest track on the album, but still quite good.  'Eriatarka' combines balladish, effecting verses with a jagged, striking chorus too good effect.  The transition between the two is particularly sweet, with the slight eerie melody underneath the synchronized pounding of the guitar and organ  'Cicatriz ESP' is most notable for it's extremely long instrumental break.  The minimalist stuff in the very middle isn't so interesting, but the dense, weaving solos are quite nice.  The core of the song is excellent, with some of the finest, most memorable vocal lines on the album, and a very powerful chorus.  'This Apparatus Must Be Unearthed' has lots of punky energy, particularly in the hypnotic chorus, but the real best part is the middle break, with a sad and beautiful dual guitar line giving way to some intense, slow building vocals. (Cedric's shrieking, `And now it won't be long' is one of the most powerful moments on the album.  'Televators' is a ballad, and an excellent one, with some nice acoustic guitar and lots of genuine emotional power.  'Take the Veil Cerpin Taxt' closes the album.  It's got another extended middle break, which sounds pretty good, though it doesn't seem to be completely appropriate to the song.  The core of the song is probably most intense and powerful one on the album, and it comes to a devastating, closing section.<br /><br />Normally I don't go for arty gibberish in the lyrics, but they do it pretty well.  Not that I give a damn about the lyrics, in the big picture.  The artwork is pretty nice too.  Yeah, this album rules.  Fans of ATDI should like this.es.  Fans of ATDI should like this.

B00005JLKN|5.0|It is odd that the third best of the 'Lector' novels written by Thomas Harris should turn out to be every bit as good as the others when taken to film.  Much is due to Brett Ratner's ability to stay focused on creating an unselfconscious story line that sticks to the material and the atmospherics around it.  Another large amount is due to Anthony Hopkins ability to recreate a character who exudes evil and fear.  But the entire cast of this film manage to play their parts well.<br /><br />This is the prequel (or near prequel) to the events in Silence of the Lambs.  Edward Norton plays Will Graham, the FBI agent who brought Lector to justice in the first case.  He has 'escaped' from seeking serial killers and is now making an anonymous life repairing boats.  But his retirement is short-lived as Jack Crawford (Harvey Keitel) seeks Will out for help on a troubling case where entire families are being killed in a grim ritual.  As we quickly find out, one of the things that's wanted is for Will to work with Lector again, this time with the mad psychiatrist behind thick plate glass and bars.<br /><br />What we find out early in the film is that the new killer is somehow linked to the old.  Lector's uncanny ability to reach out and manipulate minds is still strong, and the real story is Will Graham's struggle to evade Lector's plans while trying to identify the killer with Lecter's help.  The detective and his family are the goats in a dark hunting game.<br /><br />Hopkins plays Lecter to perfection.  Not the slick Lecter of Silence, but as a man still developing his style.  For all his ego, Lecter's real problem is his inability to see Will Graham as anything but an alter-ego.  The agent, who survived catching Lecter only by accident has no such self-delusions.  His honest brilliance is a counterpoint to Lecter's deviousness.<br /><br />Another near perfect acting Job is done by Ralph Fienne, who plays Francis Dolahyde, the Red Dragon of the title.  This isn't a hysterical portrait.  Dolarhyde has his own brilliance despite his emotional ineptness, and Fienne brings this out perfectly, capturing Dolarhyde's fumbling love affair with Reba and his power as a controlled killer with surprising sympathy.<br /><br />The extras consist of commentaries, interviews and the usual 'making of' film.  I tend to look askance at the modern habit of expanding the credence of a film by piling on self-important tidbits, but these are well done, and enhance the viewing experience by surfacing some of the fine details that make this a successful film.sterical portrait. B000000OQF|5.0|Appetite For Destruction (1987.), Guns n' Roses' first studio album<br /><br />Appetite For Destruction, Guns N' Roses 1987 debut is one of those albums that should be in any person's record collection, no question. In my opinion, this is the greatest debut album of all time (even more so than Led Zeppelin I or Hendrix's 'Are You Experienced') and furthermore, is one of the greatest albums of ALL TIME.<br /><br />Guns N' Roses, in many ways, reinvented heavy rock/metal in the few albums that they actually made and this is their finest example. The album simply does not contain one remotely weak track - each song just has that unsurpassable energy, passion and uniqueness. Saying that, if you scorn any lyrics/themes of an explicit nature, then this album is NOT for you. However, this is by no means a negative on the album as in many ways that was what this band were all about. Many of the lyrics may seem pretty strong in that respect (in some of the tracks at least) but it was the band's way of getting across their message on loads of issues and anyway isn't a realistic approach the best way?<br /><br />So the tracks themselves. There are a number of tracks on the album which most people will know. 'Welcome to the Jungle' is one of these, a great album opener with Axl Rose screaming in his familiar protesting manner which characterises the GnR sound. A similar theme to this is seen in 'Out ta get me' - another great track - i'm sure Axl Rose will be still telling us he's 'innocent' for decades to come! 'Paradise City' is one of the really well known 'anthem' style tracks which GnR produced. I personally think its a little overrated, its still brilliant and surges to a great climax at the end. 'Sweet Child O' Mine' though deserves all of the credit it is given - fantastic lyrics coupled with some killer guitar work from Slash make this one a classic.<br /><br />So, the above are the tracks which most people will know - however, the other 8 tracks the album has to offer are just as good, if not better and deserve just as much credit in my opinion. 'Your Crazy' and 'Mr. Brownstone' are songs that may need a few listens to appreciate but they are both powerful in their own way. 'Rocket Queen' is by far the most underrated track on the album and is my personal favourite song on Appetite. It builds up perfectly and the guitar work at the end is brillaint. 'Its So Easy', 'Nightrain', 'My Michelle' and 'Think About You' are all great hard rocking tracks too which again show GnR doin metal at its best!<br /><br />This album may be 18 years old but when you listen to it, it has that sound to it that makes it seem as though it was made yesterday (although it is light years better than most current music!) This album certainly broadend my passion for classic rock. Listening to this showed me that all of the greatest albums were NOT just made in the late 60's and early 70's as I had previously thought. Appetite is up there with the best. There will always be people who knock this band, calling them a bunch of wifebeaters and subsequently refusing to listen to them or those who see them as a band who are just redoing what previous groups had done just at a later time. All I can say is do not listen to any of these criticisms because you will be dismissing a truly great album which holds a deserved high place in rock history. This is one of my favourite albums and i'm sure I'm not the only one who says this!<br /><br />Not bad for a debut ...........and deserve just as much credit in my opinion. 'Your Crazy' and 'Mr. Brownstone' are songs that may need a few listens to appreciate but they are both powerful in their own way. 'Rocket Queen' is by far the most underrated track on the album and is my personal favourite song on Appetite. It builds up perfectly and the guitar work at the end is brillaint. 'Its So Easy', 'Nightrain', 'My Michelle' and 'Think About You' are all great hard rocking tracks too which again show GnR doin metal at its best!    This album may be 18 years old but when you listen to it, it has that sound to it that makes it seem as though it was made yesterday (although it is light years better than most current music!) This album certainly broadend my passion for classic rock. Listening to this showed me that all of the greatest albums were NOT just made in the late 60's and early 70's as I had previously thought. Appetite is up there with the best. B000002U82|5.0|One night as I was going through my dad's LP collection last year, I stumbled upon this album. I knew that there was a lot of hype surrounding it, and at the time I was mostly into Zeppelin.  I set it on the turntable and was simply blown away. Firsly, let me state that the sound quality of this album is undeniably the best I've ever heard on any recording, be it LP or CD. Alan Parsons is a genius, and the new 16-track equipment at Abbey Road didn't hinder, either.  The album starts out with a heartbeat, the same way it ends. It gets louder and louder until Speak to Me ends and Breathe comes in, with Gilmour's lap-steel and Waters' bass. This eventually melds into On the Run, with Wright on the new VCS3 with a sequencer they had obtained at the time. The repetitive synth riff keeps time while various effects are added in. When I listen to On the Run, I feel as if I am in a train station running alongside a train.  On the Run eventually leads to Time, starting out with the trademark alarm clocks and short drum/guitar intro. The lyrics tell of how one shouldn't waste time, as life is only so long. The solo is compact, but very expressive. The organ work on this piece of good, but Wright still has some more tricks up his sleeve with The Great Gig in the Sky, featuring Doris Troy's vocal solo and some excellent piano work.  The Great Gig in the Sky leads to Money, with its signature bassline and cash register sounds. The time change is also very intriguing. It's not hard to see why this became a hit, although it is ironic that the song describes exactly what it made Floyd.  Then side A is over (or just a pause if you have the CD) and   Us and Them comes in with an organ/piano intro and sax piece, gradually leading to the lyrics. This song describes war and how it only ends up causing everlasting problems in the form of death and destruction, and how the heat of the moment leads to fatal mistakes (\\"and who knows which is which, and who is who?\\").  Us and Them ends and quickly transitions to Any Colour You Like, with absolutely breathtaking synthesizer work. Gilmour's guitar and Mason's drums aren't too shabby, either. Ending with more synthesizer riffs, the classic Brain Damage takes the center stage, talking about insanity and how \\"if the band you're in starts playing different tunes, I'll see you on the dark side of the moon.\\" Brain Damage ends with yet another synthesizer tune, and goes into the grand finale Eclipse, showcasing Wright's Hammond organ and ends with the classic line: \\"there is no dark side of the moon really; matter of fact, it's all dark.\\"  All in all, this is a must-have for anyone who appreciates music. I find that I cannot listen to only one track; I usually end up starting the whole thing over as this album is really just one big song. Waters, Gilmour, Wright, Mason, and even Parsons deserve a medal for their work on this masterpiece.
B000268QB2|5.0|Hopes and Fears is incredible!  I am completely addicted to this CD...cannot stop listening!  What makes Keane's sound so alluring is the combination of Tom Chaplin's incredible voice, the band's choice of piano over the usual guitar, and the poetic depth of all their lyrics. I highly recommend this CD!
0385474547|4.0|<br />The story things fall apart by Chinua Achebe is about the Ibo people of Africa and specifically Okonkwo's family. In the story missionaries come and set up a church and eventually imperialism. Imperialism is The policy of extending a nation's authority by territorial acquisition or by the establishment of economic and political domination over other nations. The imperialism that was instilled in the Ibo people had a negative effect on the people of the tribe. There are many reasons why the imperialism was bad for the tribe one example is the resistance that some of the tribe had and the openness that the other half of the tribe had against change. \\"The new religion and government and the trading stores were very much in the peoples minds. There were still many who saw these new institutions as evil...\\"(pg 182-3). Another example is that it tore families apart \\"How could he have begotten a son like Nwoye, degenerate and effeminate? Perhaps he was not his son.\\"(pg 153 ) <br />

The Ruby/Picard confrontation is the zenith of this subplot and it is both sublime and superlative. <br /> <br />Special effects:  They're good.  But by 2005, people will re-visit the movie and think that the effects look cheap.  Then they'll try getting into the plot and some of themmight ask \\"Why did I like this slop?  That's why basing a movie on its effects never works; special effects always become dated.  The plot and characterizations don't. <br /> <br />The bad:  <br /> <br />The Picard/Borg subplot:  Let's figure this out:  The Federaton gives Picard their new flagship and then tells Picard to go play tiddleywinks on the Romulan border just as the Borg invasion commences.  Now if the Federation execs can't trust Picard whenever a Borg dare spouts off the usual dreary dialogue drivel, why give him the supposedly best ship out there?!  Isn't that, well, dumb?   <br /> <br />More intersting is this:  The \\"E\\" is situated at the Romulan border and the Borg strike.  They hear over subspace comm that the Feds are losing.  Picard and Data do their little song and joke and 'disobey orders' and head to Earth.  That's EARTH.  Hardly the neighbor of the Romulan neutral zone.  Even at warp 9.9, it's BOGUS to think for even one attosecond that they'd make it back in time to save the day.  This is very sloppy writing, and we're not beyond the first 10 minutes yet!! <br /> <br />Most interestingly of it all - given the previous statement, how come all the Federation ships instantly obey Picard who breaks orders (with Data being a 2nd rate Spock, no less in an awful so-called humorous moment) to go concentrate their firepower on the one area of the Borg ship? <br /> <br />And for a species that proclaims to be able to rapidly adapt, the Borg keep sending o n l y  o n e  c u b e  to take over the Federation.  Having been in tussle against the Federation before, you think they'd send TWO cube ships and be done with it, but nooooo.  Worse, the usual issue of conveniently being able to kill Borg in one scene, followed by a scene where they adapt, and then later another scene where lo and behold they can kill some more Borg again became tiresome. <br /> <br />Time travel.  How many more times do we need to see a sloppily written way to get everybody back intime.  Even better, with the Enterprise heavily damaged and having its deflector removed, I'd wonder HOW they could get back to the 24th century so easily... <br /> <br />\\"Watch you're future's end\\" says the Queen.  Never mind that the Queen is totally incongrous with what we've been led to believe about the Borg in the past.  Her comment is stupid.  Picard and the gang have already ecounted the Borg and even have lives.  Had this scene been in the 24th century, it might be passable.  But with using time-travel (WHY?  There is no need to except to deliver us the means to add the Zephram Cochrane subplot which is utterly atrocious and pointless), this big phrase of hers loses all meaning because we already know they're going to win.  More sloppy writing, if there hadn't been enough at this point! <br /> <br />The comedy, it shouldn't be called 'humor':  Ever since Trek IV, Paramount seems intent on ensuring every Trek movie gets a huge dose of humor (except for 'Nemesis', which is ironically the biggest joke of them all...).  Guess what?  It ain't funny in this one.  It's so awful, it's even embarrasing in scenes.  This movie was presented to me as being a suspenseful adventure and what we truly got was this farce?!  Oobie doobie this! <br /> <br />The music.  Jerry Goldsmith is not at his best here.  One example is the Borg battle music's intro; it's B-material at best, overly pompous and embarrassing to listen to at worst.  Something about the music doesn't fit the movie.  Goldsmith's done better (namely the first Trek film)  What was wrong with Dennis McCarthy's style?  Or, better yet, why not get Ron Jones to do the music?  Oh yeah, he was fired because his style was too lively and engaging and didn't put people to sleep while watching the show. <br /> <br />Continuity flubs:  They exist in great numbers here.  Non-trekkies won't care because they won't see the goofs.  Trekkies who like the Kirk era WILL care.  (Obviously I prefer the Kirk era, generally, but Insurrection Special Edition hasn't been released yet...)  Fans of the Next Generation will love anything it all regardless. (try to sit through 'Nemesis' and you'll know quickly what I mean...) <br /> <br />Production flubs:  Barclay's toupee and some other trifling bits, there's a surprisingly good scene where Ruby is threatening Picard with a phaser.  He ultimately gets her to stand down, but when she hands him the phaser you can see it light up.  Why didn't Picard die as he did say it was set to kill? <br /> <br />And worst of all:  Cameos from two of Star Trek Voyager's cast for no reason:  The McCoy ripoff hologram doctor... and Neelix minus his makeup in the holodeck ballroom recreation.  Just when you thought that Michael Dorn's butting into Trek 6 was bad enough, now we get two from a far worse spinoff.  (not to dis Mr. Dorn, I rather liked how they were making continuity... and for once not wilfully breaking it, as can be seen in Generations and 1st Contact...) <br /> <br />Along with time travel, other bogus conveniences include how easy it is to turn off the holodeck safety mechanism (which should also mean that when one exits the holodeck, any bullets would also vanish, yes?) <br /> <br />Ultimately?  Go buy \\"Generations\\" instead.  It feels even more like an overlong TV episode, but despite its problems it's at least got the humor part done well.
B00004T9UF|5.0|Let me just write a little prequel to my review. Don't immediately think that I am that corny guy who worships anything Em does. In fact, I think he should be put in jail for what he did on the latest Pac release and G-unit is the worst thing that happened to hip-hop since Vanilla Ice. However, this is a true jewel that should not be slept on.  This is the album that turned Em into a huge sensation that he is now. This is the album, that allows Eminem to release unbelievable crap like \\"Encore\\" nowadays and still have people buying it. This is the album that got me into rap.       Before \\"The Marshall Mathers LP\\" Em had \\"The Slim shady LP \\" which was alright and his underground LP \\"Ifinite\\" which was pretty good, however lacking the world-famous Slim Shady persona. The Slim Shady LP goes triple platinum and Em becomes an overnight celebrity. This album is the reaction of a young white rapper cornered by fame, a lyrical \\"Up yours\\" to all the critics and other people who threw obstacles in his life path.        But what makes it a masterpeace is the lyrical flow. Em throws jaw-dropping rhymes, mad flavour and phat metaphors on every bar. Whether he is being funny:  \\"Willl Smith doesn't have to cus in his raps to sell records  well I do, so f*** him and f*** you too\\"  or he is dead serious:    \\"When a dude's gettin bullied and shoots up his school  and they blame it on Marilyn ... and the heroin  Where were the parents at? And look where it's at  Middle America, now it's a tragedy  Now it's so sad to see, an upper class ci-ty  havin this happenin ...    Em always delivers. The beats are of course tight because of the man behind them (c'mon, Dre even makes Game's CD worth listening).     Of course this album has every church-going catholic across America have his mouth filled with foam. This album is filled with violent images such as killing his wife or raping his mother, but it is because Em dares to exploit the freedom of speech to its fullest. And when he dares he doesn't just do it boldly in order for his album to top the record sales, he incorporates these bold anger-lashing statements in his state-of-the-art rhymes over tight beats.  Unfortunately, we won't ever see or hear Eminem like this. He got stinking ritch after this album and lost his longing for good rhymes or for limit-pushing controversy. Maybe it is for good, because this crafted masterpiece can't ever be outdone not   by Em himself, not by anybody else.
B0002Z0EYK|2.0|I think it is rather ironic the editorial reviewer said that he recommended TROY, \\"especially if you've never read Homer's Illiad.\\" It's true, reading the book would only ruin the movie for you. I am not an intellectual snob, nor do I believe that contemporary films shouldn't adapt material, but I do have a problem when it distorts the original intent of the author and especially when it does it poorly. Homer chronicled the duality and the harshness of Greek society in his time and he did it brilliantly. His epic was about the destructiveness of anger and revenge. The Greeks worshipped the gods much as people worship God today, in a variety of ways: some out of love, some to further their own interests, for revenge or to appear pious, but their concept of the gods was woven deeply in the fabric of their consciousness; they had complex relationships with their gods; fraternal, dependent, fearful, resentful and jealous and really was so much part of their culture, it seems completely odd to cut that whole part of their society out- all of it was completely absent from the movie and it flattens the depth of the story. It's like trying to write a biography of Saint Francis of Assisi and removing all references to God.<br /><br />And Brad Pitt's performance is a mute interpretation of Achilles. The Iliad's Achilles was actually extremely verbose, passionate and fractious. Homer was amazing at drawing fully fleshed characters, his stories were exciting adventures and morals for their time.  The Iliad is a great book; Homer's writing just pulls you in. There was no need to edit out so much- for example, the hissy fit between Achilles and Agamemnon which has terrible consequences on the war between Greece and Troy. Yes, it starts with Paris stealing away Helen of Troy, but when the two arrogant, conceited soldiers of fortune, Agamemnon and Achilles fight over their \\"spoils of war\\" from a previous battle, the true impact of their argument sets them and all the vast populace of Greece and Troy onto a path of misery and despair. Agamemnon had divided up the loot from a village he and Achilles had razed and looted and included in Achilles' booty was a woman captured from one of the villages: the maiden Briseis. When Agamemnon is forced to return his ill-gotten gains, he takes back Briseis for himself. Achilles, in a snit, then refuses to help the Greeks in their battle against Troy anymore. Zeus comes to the aid of the Trojans and the Greeks suffer great losses without the leadership of the great Achilles. Also, Achilles' beloved friend Patroclus, takes his place in battle and is killed. Achilles howling in grief over his loss, realises how his anger and petty need for revenge has destroyed so many innocents. The book opens with this comment on how such destruction all came down to one man's anger: \\"Goddess, sing the rage of Achilles, murderous, doomed anger that cost the Acheans countless losses, hurling down to the house of death so many sturdy souls, their bodies made carrion feasts for the birds and dogs.\\" Isn't that amazing? Go read the rest.ce and Troy onto a path of misery and despair. Agamemnon had divided up the loot from a village he and Achilles had razed and looted and included in Achilles' booty was a woman captured from one of the villages: the maiden Briseis. When Agamemnon is forced to return his ill-gotten gains, he takes back Briseis for himself. Achilles, in a snit, then refuses to help the Greeks in their battle against Troy anymore. Zeus comes to the aid of the Trojans and the Greeks suffer great losses without the leadership of the great Achilles. Also, Achilles' beloved friend Patroclus, takes his place in battle and is killed. The book opens with this comment on how such destruction all came down to one man's anger: \\"Goddess, sing the rage of Achilles, murderous, doomed anger that cost the Acheans countless losses, hurling down to the house of death so many sturdy souls, their bodies made carrion feasts for the birds and dogs.\\" Isn't that amazing? B000002OVJ|5.0|Live At Leeds (1970.), a Who concert<br /><br />The Who's 'Live at Leeds', recorded on 14th February 1970, is definitely THE essential Who album (along with Who's Next). This album shows why the Who had a great reputation for performing live - the finesse, brilliance and sheer entertainment this album gives shows this.<br /><br />The Live at Leeds album was originally remastered in the late 1990's in superb fashion - now most of the concert which the band played at Leeds University is aavailable on the CD (over 70 minutes now as opposed to the marginally over 40 minutes version on the old vinyls which were released at the time). Then, more recently in 2002, this, the Deluxe Edition, was released which is a 2 CD version which has a performance of 'Tommy', performed just after the 'Live at Leeds' concert. The Tommy performance is amazing and is near flawless - its like just listening to the studio album, if not better. The Deluxe edition also comes with an extensive booklet with info about the tracks, quotes, pictures etc. If your thinking of buying this album, which I strongly recommend you do, especially if your a Who fan, then get the Deluxe Edition - the extras which the original remaster CD does not incorporate make it well worth the investment.<br /><br />So, which songs did the Who play at the 'Live at Leeds' concert?<br /><br />They start the whole thing off with a track called 'Heaven and Hell' which is very much an underrated and underplayed John Entwhistle Track. Following this is 'I Can't Explain', 'Tattoo' and 'Fortune Teller'. They then do some of their hits such as 'Substitute' before then doing a version of their 'mini opera' from 1967 called 'A quick one whilst he's away' which is a story about a girl guide being seduced by Ivor the Old Engine Driver - it makes quite an amusing story. They follow this with a brilliant cover of 'Summertime Blues' and then 'Shakin' All Over'. A mammoth performance of My Generation follows this which is basically the hit extended into a 10+ minute jam - its really good entertainment. They finish off with 'Magic Bus' in a lighthearted but great fashion.<br /><br />All in all, the concert the Who gave was fantastic. The Who knew how to interact with and entertain the crowd and you'll see this throughout the album, especially with the 'Quick One' performance. Keith Moon, as you'll hear was always willing to chirp in with amusing comments (as he was always known to do), another thing to listen out for! The Who simply are one of the greatest bands of all time and certainly one of the best on the live stage (there is certainly more to their performances than the guitar smashing at the end - though I'm not sure they mutilated their instruments at this one!).<br /><br />BUY THIS LIVE CD and make it the DELUXE EDITION!am - its really good entertainment. They finish off with 'Magic Bus' in a lighthearted but great fashion.     All in all, the concert the Who gave was fantastic. The Who knew how to interact with and entertain the crowd and you'll see this throughout the album, especially with the 'Quick One' performance. Keith Moon, as you'll hear was always willing to chirp in with amusing comments (as he was always known to do), another thing to listen out for! The Who simply are one of the greatest bands of all time and certainly one of the best on the live stage (there is certainly more to their performances than the guitar smashing at the end - though I'm not sure they mutilated their instruments at this one!).     BUY THIS LIVE CD and make it the DELUXE EDITION!

But the Imperialists don't just disrespect their religion they also disrespected the people themselves when they just barged right into there villages and built the own churches and places to stay.  It just seemed like the Ibo people were a lot more peaceful and happy before the imperialists arrived.

B0006A9FKA|4.0|It's not easy to send up a movie style that already rarely takes itself too seriously, but, with some great one-liners and visual gags, Shaun of the Dead succeeds most of the time as both an enjoyable spoof and as a fond tribute to the Romero-esque genre.<br /><br />The characterisation is surprisingly strong and Shaun's (brilliantly played by Simon Pegg) tribulations and hang-ups will elicit nods of recognition from many of us I expect!<br /><br />Some extremely laddish humour, interspersed with wry and often very perceptive observational comedy, ensures continued interest, and the action scenes are genuinely dramatic and effective.<br /><br />Inspired (ironic) choice of soundtrack material too.<br /><br />Huge amount of extras make this great value for money.<br /><br />Not Oscar material maybe, but still a highly entertaining movie, which should appeal to those who enjoy the likes of the Evil Dead 2/3 and American Werewolf in London. Like those movies, Shaun of the Dead is almost certainly destined for similar cult status.
B000005RQT|5.0|In Rock (1970.), Deep Purple's fourth studio album<br /><br />Deep Purple's 1970 release saw the band find what they were to prove themselves to be a master of, classic hard rock. Deep Purple had undergone a lot of change in the previous 6 months/year before this album was recorded. The Mark I (original Deep Purple line-up) which produced 3, to many quite unknown (but not bad) albums was no more. Vocalist Rod Evans and bassist Nic Simper left the band in mid 1969 and the remaining members had to start from scratch. However, the Mark II line up was to rise out of the ashes of the previous line up with massive success over the 1969-1973 which they were together. New vocalist Ian Gillan and bassist Roger Glover along with the classic guitar playing of Ritchie Blackmore, whizz keyboard skills of Jon Lord and powerful drumming of Ian Paice were to be a winning formula. Their first effort, this one, was to be an excellent hard-rocking starting effort.<br /><br />Deep Purple in Rock is by far one of the heaviest albums of its time with its thick but racy guitar lines, heavy bass and overlay keyboard complexion however this is what gives it great passion and drive and makes it one of the true original 'heavy metal' albums. People often say that Black Sabbath are the godfathers of heavy metal but in my opinion, Deep Purple come very close to their level. It is true to say that this album is not quite as refined as later Mark II works such as Machine Head and Fireball but you can see them approaching these later works with this album. The album itself has a great cover, depicting the band faces set 'In Rock' instead of the US Presidents carved into Mount Rushmore. It often amazes me how this album made very little impression in the US album charts, reaching only #143!!!!! Still it had good success in the UK, reaching #4.<br /><br />This album contains some real heavy tracks with loads of drive. The 25th Anniversary Edition, remastered and put together in 1995 is excellent and is the version of this album to get (it comes with a cd case with imprints of the Mark II bands signatures). The album is greatly expanded on the Anniversary Edition and includes the 'A' side classic, Black Night (the remaster and an unedited remix is available on this CD) - this is a great track known to many - the remix of it is brilliant with an extended guitar solo from Blackmore which rocks hard. Some extra tracks, 'Jam Stew' and 'Cry Free' are included which are good worthy additions. A piano version and remix of 'Speed King' and a 'Flight of the Rat' remix are also available which further enhance the effects of Deep Purples work.<br /><br />So these are the extras on the anniversary edition, what about the actual 7 tracks on the album? All of them are fab, even if they do occasionally have a slightly unrefined edge to them. Speed King is a crashing opener and a true Deep Purple classic - a whilrling guitar opening leads into a track which rather on the lines of a later masterpiece 'Highway Star' which features on Machine Head. Bloodsucker is a heavy follow up with a great aggressive riff - Gillans screaming at the end give the track a piercing but kind of haunting finish. 'Child in Time' is a 10+ minute Deep Purple epic which builds to an epic climax in the middle of the track then cleverly returns to the more thoughtful style shown in the opening part of the track. 'Flight of the Rat' for me is the best track on the album, 7 minutes of metal with some brilliant riffs and some nifty keyboard work from Lord. 'Into the Fire' and 'Living Wreck' follow this and both are heavy rockers, even if they are not stand out songs. 'Hard Loving Man' makes a blasting finale to the album which pounding lines of keyboard and guitar.<br /><br />So, it measures up pretty good. I would never put 'In Rock' alongside Machine Head (which I think deserves 6 stars at the very least!) but still it is deserving of all the praise it gets and of a 5 star rating. What you witness here is, in my mind the true birth of Deep Purple, one of the great heavy rock bands that have graced this earth. It has certainly given me the incentive to buy more of Deep Purple's albums both studio and live.le, one of the great heavy rock bands that have graced this earth. It has certainly given me the incentive to buy more of Deep Purple's albums both studio and live.
B000002MP2|5.0|I remember receiving my first copy of Dookie for Christmas in 1994 on cassette, and being only ten years old and very impressionable, I got quite a bit of visceral entertainment out of Green Day's music and image. I remember listening to the tape over and over again (so much so that the tape player ate it), all while looking at the \\"dirty\\" cartoons and swear words within the booklet, thinking how cool it all was. At the time, I didn't have much of a musical identity, so I'd like to think of Green Day as one of the bands that shaped me. No doubt, Green Day's major label breakthrough, \\"Dookie,\\" is an influential album. Although critics would never give it as much credit as Nirvana's \\"Nevermind,\\" it has had a similar impact on our culture. For one thing, Green Day are one of the few groups to have survived the 90's and aged with grace -- even outdoing themselves with the acclaimed, award winning \\"American Idiot.\\" Their influence is obvious in countless groups out there today -- although, just as it always goes, the formula got watered down, and half of what your hear today isn't this good. I'm not gonna pretend to be a punk snob, or an elitist of some sort. All I can tell you is that \\"Dookie\\" is a great album. Everyone knows the infamous singles, such as \\"When I Come Around,\\" \\"Longview,\\" \\"Basketcase\\" and \\"Welcome To Paradise,\\" afterall, you couldn't turn on the radio or MTV without hearing them. But \\"Dookie\\" is more than just it's singles. Songs like \\"Burnout,\\" \\"Having A Blast\\" \\"Pulling Teeth\\" and \\"F.O.D.\\" hold up to the same standard set by the more popular tunes. However, the shining moment, and the most mature is \\"Coming Clean,\\" a daring song that gracefully tackles the difficult and awkward subject of homophobia and coming out of the closet -- maybe now you understand why the band is so adamantly against Bush. Who knew an album named after human waste could be so brilliant and stand the test of time so well? Maybe I'm just being biased, because this one of the few albums I bought before hitting puberty that I still enjoy just as much today.  But I'm sure plenty of people can tell you a similar story. Like the title says, it's an important album, but it doesn't take itself too seriously, which means you can enjoy it anytime, anyday.albums I bought before hitting puberty that I still enjoy just as much today.  But I'm sure plenty of people can tell you a similar story. Like the title says, it's an important album, but it doesn't take itself too seriously, which means you can enjoy it anytime, anyday.

B00000DOYP|5.0|The very thought of Genesis' 1980 album \\"Duke\\" receiving a considerable amount of hostility is truly unjust and, frankly, ridiculous.  \\"Duke\\", originally released on March 31, 1980, is, in some ways, a transitional record, but here's the thing...  Serious fans realize that Genesis did not suddenly become a \\"pop\\" band overnight--the shift to a less progressive, more \\"pop\\"-ish sound was an extremely gradual one, & that said, a case can very much be made that every Genesis album from 1976 through 1983 are transitional ones.  This album, sonically, is nearly identical to the previous album \\"...And Then There Were Three\\"--both albums featured production by David Hentschel.      To put it a certain way, I think if \\"Duke\\" had been released by an obscure band, it would have an absolutely fanatical cult following.  As it is, it somehow seems to have gotten something of a bad rap with its increasing prominence of Phil Collins in the songwriting department.  However, an album of this caliber can only be supplied by the likes of Banks, Collins, & Rutherford.  If you think this is a straightforward pop-rock record, obviously the only tracks from it that you`re familiar with are \\"Misunderstanding\\" and \\"Turn It On Again\\".      Classify the album however you want though--the bottom line is that this is a masterpiece.  Tony Banks' compositional brilliance is in serious abundance on this album, displaying why he is so widely admired by so many progressive rock fans.  Vocally, Phil is in a weirdly transitional phase on \\"Duke\\"--his vocals are expressive & powerful, yet throughout the album, there's a `little guy' humbleness to his vocals, something that, strangely, was almost completely washed away even by the time of Phil's debut solo album \\"Face Value\\" from early the following year.  Listen to Phil's vocals on Tony's gloomy, soothing, and dreamy ballad \\"Heathaze\\", or on Mike Rutherford's slightly weepy, yet soulful, soaring ballad \\"Alone Tonight\\", and you'll see what I mean--you never really heard that timbre from Phil ever again.  It's almost as if after this album was completed Phil got an extra shot of testosterone.      Also, I want to point out the drumming.  Phil's crisp, fluent drumming on here, which is brilliantly captured in the mix, is incredible.  I'm not exactly sure about the chronology, but I *think* the recording of \\"Duke\\" came just before Phil, along with Hugh Padgham and Steve Lillywhite (while working on the third \\"Peter Gabriel\\" album), hit upon the gated \\"In the Air Tonight\\" drum sound that was soon to become a trademark of his.      The album opens with \\"Behind the Lines\\", which has an exciting, fast-paced 2+ minute instrumental intro before the wonderfully melodic, mellower song portion begins.  \\"Duchess\\" also starts off with a 2+ minute instrumental portion which features atmospheric drum machine, washes of guitar, and ethereal keyboard chord changes from Banks--it's really beautiful, and it builds into the main song portion which has soaring Phil vocals, singing a haunting tale about the rise and fall of a female singer.  Rutherford's \\"Man of Our Times\\" is an anthemic song loaded with catchy riffs that explodes out of the speakers/ headphones--it features searing vocals from Collins that, strangely, are majorly buried in the dense mix.      The two hit singles are terrific as well.  \\"Misunderstanding\\" (which is indeed highly reminiscent of Sly & the Family Stone's \\"Hot Fun in the Summertime\\") is a sophisticated, yearning mid-tempo love song.  And \\"Turn It On Again\\" has an ultra-catchy Rutherford guitar riff, and it's sort of a feel-good tune, but with a highly contemplative feel to it.      Phil also delivers a really hard-hittingly emotional ballad with \\"Please Don't Ask\\", a track which strongly underlines how unfair the criticism Phil has received about his songwriting over the years really is.  Listen to the chord changes and the elegant shifts of key that masterfully intertwine with the lyrics of the song, heightening its emotional impact.      Genesis bring closure to the album in emphatic fashion with the multi-part, mostly instrumental \\"Duke's Travels\\" which really takes you on a musical journey, and it segues into the last track, \\"Duke's End\\", which is a reprise of the intro to \\"Behind the Lines\\".      All that said, calling this album a sellout pop-rock simply doesn't pan out.  \\"Duke\\" is an album that offers a wealth of astonishing musicality, masterful use of dynamics, and brilliant composition.  I've been listening to \\"Duke\\" since I was a kid, and my understanding, respect, and admiration of it has only grown since then.  And with so much emotionally resonant music here, it's an album that can go a long way to help pull you through the dark phases of your life as well.  If you've got a serious love for music, you can't go wrong with this stunning must-have album.    (P.S.  One gripe I have with both this CD version and the later \\"original recording remastered\\" version is that the track mark dividing \\"Dutchess\\" & \\"Guide Vocal\\" was improperly inserted--that bit you hear at the beginning of track 3 is actually the closing portion of \\"Dutchess\\", not the intro to \\"Guide Vocal\\".)
B0001Z363W|5.0|OK, I read some of the negative reviews and I must say, they are wrong... so very wrong.  Zakk Wylde is probably one of the most talented musicians out there... I can think of very few modern guitarists that would come close.  Hangover Music solidifies Zakk as a musician by showing his depth.  This is clearly an exemplary piece of work becuase of the depth involved.  True that it is certainly a change from some of his other music, it is clearly a different kind of punch than what Stronger than Death or The Blessed Hellride offer.  I consider this to be one of the best pieces of music I own.
B0002Z1EG2|4.0|Twain's first greatest hits collection provides exceptionally generous coverage of her hit-making career, with 17 top-charters and three new songs, including her recent single, \\"Party of Two.\\" And though Twain's songs don't always hold up under critical scrutiny (banal lyrics like \\"take a trip, take control, take advice from someone you know,\\" abound), there's no doubting the exceptional quality of these catchy radio gems.<br /><br />Together with producer/husband Mutt Lange, Twain has fashioned a sound that is like highly lacquered wood - plenty of eye-catching gloss with little exposed grain. Their lyrics speak of personal empowerment and minor disappointment, but never ford any real heart-wrenching waters. This is a canny move for creating radio hits, but it's not nearly as compelling across a 21-track album. Similarly, Lange's production choices, the fiddle sound and harmony stylings, are like ear candy for a few tracks, but become cavity-inducing sugar by mid-CD.<br /><br />Unusually, the tracks are presented in reverse chronological order, painting a sonic picture of Twain moving from the MOR pop and dance music of \\"Up!\\" to the twangier country sounds of \\"The Woman in Me.\\" The drum  machines, synthesizers and ZZ Top-like guitar finally give way to acoustics, dobro and harmonica on track 12, \\"No One Needs to Know,\\" and the coy vocal of \\"Whose Bed Have Your Boots Been Under\\" is supported by compelling close harmonies and tinkling honky-tonk piano.<br /><br />New tracks include two versions of the call-and-response duet \\"Party For Two,\\" one with Billy Currington and one with Sugar Ray's Mark McGrath, the apologetic ballad \\"Don't\\" and the bubblegummy honky-tonker, \\"I Ain't No Quitter.\\" There's no disputing that Twain and Lange make superb music, and that Twain is a compelling vocalist. But like many sweets, the bulk of their hit catalog is filled with empty calories - a fine treat, but not a musical meal.
